results.title: Sorok pervyy = The Forty first
results.brief_description:
Set during the civil war in Turkestan, ‘The Forty First’ is a remake of the story of romance with a Red woman commander and her captive White officer. In a remote region of Russia, skirmishes are fought between two armies in conflict. The conditions are trying - in the sand dunes of eastern Russia there are few resources for the embattled soldiers. A courageous sharpshooter, the commander is escorting her prisoner to his new confines when the two are marooned. Inevitably romance erupts between the enemies who are drawn into a struggle involving personal feelings and class identification. Remembering her duty, the commander makes a tragic decision, killing her lover in order to save him from capture, when the pair are rescued by Czarists. A typically patriotic Soviet drama from the 1950s that delves into an interesting wartime moral dilemma.

Credits: Director, Grigorii Chukhrai ; writer, Grigorii Koltunov ; photography, Sergei Urusevskii ; music, Nikolai Kriukov.
Cast: Izolda Izvitskaya, Oleg Strizhenov, Nikolai Kryuchkov, Nikolai Dupak, Georgiy Shapovalov.

results.title: Letyat zhuravli = The Cranes are flying
results.brief_description:
An anti-war love story set during the early years of World War II, ‘The Cranes Are Flying’ is a romantic drama about love, loss and recovery from catastrophe. When a young hospital worker hears that her fiance has been killed in the war, she is traumatised and refuses to believe it. Raped by a distant cousin during an air raid, she eventually marries him, despite feeling no love, and continues to mourn for her dead lover. A subsequent turn of events re-establishes her faith in life and her confidence returns. Winner of Best Film at the Cannes Film Festival, 1958

Credits: Producer, director, Mikhail Kalatozov ; writer, Victor Rosov ; photography, Sergei Urusevski ; music, M. Vainberg ; editing, Mariya Timofeyeva.
Cast: Tatiana Samoilova, Alexei Batalov, Vasily Merkuryev, Alexander Shvorin, Svetlana Kharitonova, Konstantin Nikitin.

results.title: Zvenigora (Musical Soundtrack)
results.brief_description:
Dovzhenko’s most audacious film combines ancient folklore with modern events in ranging over many centuries of Ukrainian history with a political aim of obliquely linking modern revolutionary Ukraine with its distant past. For Dovzhenko the fresco-like narrative was what he described as ‘a catalogue of my creative possibilities’. The four part structure with a strange quest for treasure at its centre, incorporates a series of bracketing devices to enclose such eccentric episodes as those involving a vampire-like monk, midsummer rituals on the river and a toytown battle. Also available on 16mm.

Credits: Director, Alexander Dovzhenko ; writer, Mikhail Johansen, Yuri Yurtik ; photography, Boris Zavelev.
Cast: Mikola Nademsky, Semyon Svashenko, Alexander Podorozhny.

results.title: Stachka = Strike (Musical soundtrack)
results.brief_description:
Eisenstein conceived his first film not as the portrayal of an actual historical event but as a generalised picture of a strike without individual heroes; the mass is a collective hero represented by types rather than characters.of poster-like sketches containing Eisenstein’s first experiments with montage both for direct emotional impact (collision) and for the presentation of abstract ideas (metaphor). A constructivist approach is evident in the way machinery is represented not as dominating the workers but as being enlisted by them in the struggle. Also available on VHS, LD and 16mm.

Credits: Director, Sergei Eisenstein ; photographer, E. Tisse, Vassili Khvatov ; [producer, Boris Mikhine ; script, Sergei Eisenstein, V. Pletniev, I. Kravtchunovsky, Grigori Alexandrov].
Cast: [Grigori Alexandrov, Maxim Strauch, Mikhail Gomarov], credited as Troupe of the workers Theatre.

results.title: La Rupture = The Breakup
results.creator_credit: Claude Chabrol, Cinevog Films, Euro International and Les Films de la Boetie
results.brief_description:
A wife and mother, Helene, battles to defend herself and her child against an attack by her husband Charles while he is under the influence of LSD. With his son in hospital her father-in-law moves to gain custody of the child by employing the needy Paul to spy on Helene in order to find cause. This is the fourth of Chabrol’s series of thrillers set in bourgeois households, usually involving a triangle, that began with ‘Les Biches’ (1968). It also involves a further variant on the redemption-through-the-assumption-of-guilt theme recurring in Chabrol’s films, which he found, as a critic, recurring in Hitchcock’s work. Also available on VHS.

Credits: Director, [script], Claude Chabrol ; photography, Jean Rabier ; music, Pierre Jansen ; editor, Jacques Gaillard ; sound, Guy Chichignoud.
Cast: Stephane Audran, Jean-Pierre Cassel, Michel Bouquet, Annie Cordy, Jean-Claude Drouot, Michel Duchaussoy.

Note: Based on the novel by Charlotte Armstrong “Le jour des parques”.

results.title: Smultronstallet = Wild strawberries
results.creator_credit: Ingmar Bergman, Allan Ekelund and Svensk Filmindustri
results.brief_description:
An aged professor - introverted and emotionally cold - makes a journey to collect a university award and en route relives his past through recollection, dreams and imagination. Borg emerges purged, if not wholly changed from this confrontation with self. The theme of the film, incarnated in the successive generations of the Borgs, is death-in-life, emotional-spiritual atrophy. It has been compared with King Lear and Strindberg’s Dream Play and in structure with a Bach fugue. Wild strawberries are a Swedish symbol for the emergence of spring, the rebirth of life. Also available on 16mm and VHS.

Credits: [Producer, Allan Ekelund] ; director, writer, Ingmar Bergman ; photography, Gunnar Fischer ; music, Erik Nordgren.
Cast: Victor Sjostrom, Ingrid Thulin, Bibi Andersson, Gunnar Bjornstrand.

results.title: Joi-Uchi = Rebellion (Cinemascope print)
results.creator_credit: Masaki Kobayashi, Tomoyuki Tanaka, Toshiro Mifune, Mifune Productions and Toho Kabushiki Kaisha
results.brief_description:
Isaburo is an aging swordsman loyal to the feudal system of Japanese society. His son, Yogoro is requested to marry his father’s overlord’s mistress, Ichi, with whom the lord has become displeased. Against his father’s wishes Yogoro agrees to the match, and falls in love with Ichi, who bears him a son. When the clan’s elder son dies, the lord sends for Ichi to return - but the family refuse to be parted. Supported by Isaburo, for whom life has renewed meaning, father and son join forces against the warlord, who orders the couple to commit suicide and then when they refuse, sends soldiers to execute them. Set in 1725 Japan, ‘Rebellion’ is an intriguing historical drama that pitches the samurai’s code of honour against his familial loyalties, reaching a typically bloody and beautifully choreographed finale.

Credits: Producer, Toshiro Mifune, Tomoyuki Tanaka ; director, Masaki Kobayashi ; writer, Shinobu Hashimoto ; photography, Kazuo Yamada ; music, Toru Takemitsu ; editing, Hisashi Sagara
Cast: Toshiro Mifune, Takeshi Kato, Yoko Tsukasa, Tatsuya Nakadai, Tatsuyoshi Ebara, Michiko Otsuka.

results.title: Shestaya chast mira = The Sixth part of the world
results.brief_description:
A celebration of the resources of the Soviet Union, by the pioneering Russian film-maker and avant-gardist, Dziga Vertov - a free-flowing sequence of images drawn from all corners of the country showing the wealth of the Soviet people who have overthrown the capitalist class. This film contrasts Soviet industriousness with the decadence of foreign capitalists; and Soviet plenty and freedom with the poverty and slavery of the people in capitalist countries. Dziga Vertov was the founder of the Soviet documentary and headed a group of experimental documentarists who took the name Kinoki, or Kino-Eyes. As a militant theorist he proclaimed the supremacy of what would now be called Cinema-Verite. His films and his theoretical writings have had an enormous and lasting influence on world cinema. ‘The Sixth Part of the World’ is Vertov’s lyrical cinema poem to the vast expanses of the Soviet Union, grand, complicated and exotic.

Credits: Director, writer, editing, Dziga Vertov ; photography, Mikhail Kaufman.

results.title: Viskingar och rop = Cries and whispers
results.creator_credit: Ingmar Bergman, Cinematograph for Svenska Filminstitutet and Svenska filminstitutet
results.brief_description:
Two sisters, Maria and Karin, tend their sister, Agnes, dying of cancer, in the family mansion. Over the course of the film the three sisters and the family maid, Anna, examine their past, lamenting dark and tumultuous moments. Maria is a self-centred, vain, exquisite beauty, with a shallow perspective; Karin, bitter and frigid has a history of self-mutilation and contemplates suicide; Agnes, in immense pain, is comforted by Anna the fatalistic family retainer. Bergman artfully explores the inner life of the women, detailing the history of their connectedness yet isolation from each other. With flashbacks and minimal dialogue Bergman lays out the emotional landscape of this family’s fragile bonds that strain under the imminent death of one. Clocks are a repeated motif for the passage of time, and a reminder of the women’s mortality; sound and colour play an important part in the narrative with red (wine, walls, curtains) representing the soul’s interior. Set in the late 1800s, ‘Cries and Whispers’ is an intense, disturbing and powerful family drama about repression, spirituality, sexual passion, hatred and death.

Credits: Producer, director, writer, Ingmar Bergman ; photography, Sven Nykvist ; editing, Siv Lundgren.
Cast: Harriet Andersson, Kari Sylwan, Ingrid Thulin, Liv Ullmann, Erland Josephson, Henning Moritzen.

Set in the late 1800s, ‘Cries and Whispers’ is an intense, disturbing and powerful family drama about repression, spirituality, sexual passion, hatred and death.

Credits: Producer, director, writer, Ingmar Bergman ; photography, Sven Nykvist ; editing, Siv Lundgren.
Cast: Harriet Andersson, Kari Sylwan, Ingrid Thulin, Liv Ullmann, Erland Josephson, Henning Moritzen.

results.title: Sommaren med Monika = Summer with Monika
results.creator_credit: Ingmar Bergman, Allan Ekelund and Svensk Filmindustri
results.brief_description:
A chance meeting between Harry, an errand boy, and Monika, a wild and reckless young woman from the poorer quarter of Stockholm (a strikingly assured performance by Andersson), leads to an affair and an escape from the city for a holiday on the nearby islands. The summer idyll is abruptly shattered when Monika finds that she is pregnant. While Harry accepts the responsibilities of parenthood, Monika is less willing. The light and open space of the islands is contrasted with the dark claustrophobia of the city. Also available on VHS.

Credits: Producer, Allan Ekelund ; director, Ingmar Bergman ; writers, Ingmar Bergman, Per Anders Fogelstrom ; photography, Gunnar Fischer ; music, Erik Nordgren ; editors, Tage Holmberg, Gosta Lewin.
Cast: Harriet Andersson, Lars Ekborg.
